Q1:
ONLINE SURVEY (ALTERNATE CONSENT and SURVEY ITEMS)

(IRB Approval: # Pro2019000645)



 

College of Education                                                                                        Zeynep Isik-Ercan, Ph.D. (ercan@rowan.edu) and Nicole M. Edwards, Ph.D. (edwardsn@rowan.edu)

Department of Interdisciplinary and Inclusive Education                       

James Hall, 3rd Floor                                                                                         

201 Mullica Hill Road                                                                      

Glassboro, NJ 08028

 

You are invited to participate in this online research survey entitled, Understanding the Ecology of Immigrant Families and their Integration into Camden City: Multiple Systems for Health and Well-Being of Young Children from Birth to Age 5.  You are included in this survey because you are a State level administrator who oversees and supervises supports for children from first or second generation immigrant families in the birth-5 age range.  A rough estimate of few hundred participants across 50 states will be asked to participate in completing this one-time survey. The State level administrator survey may take approximately 10 minutes to complete.  Your participation is voluntary. If you do not wish to participate in this survey, do not respond to this online survey.  Completing this survey indicates that you are voluntarily giving consent to participate in the survey.  We expect this survey to remain open until December 1, 2020.   

 

The purpose of this research study is to better understand the extent to which stakeholders and families perceive existing and desired systems and supports for immigrant families of young children. More specifically, our objectives include:

●      Understanding family and child health development and well-being in context

●      Pinpointing key partners and identifying interactions across systems of support (mapping their ecology)

●      Assessing family satisfaction with and use of available supports

●      Understanding views on stakeholder accountability and coordination needs

 

There are no risks or discomforts associated with this survey.  There may be no direct benefit to you, however, by participating in this study, you may help us understand the ways in which we can pinpoint and address roadblocks that may impede capacity building and outreach efforts.  Your response will be kept confidential.  We will store the de-identified data in a secure computer file.  Any part of the research that is published as part of this study will not include your individual information or the name of your particular place of employment.  If you have any questions, contact Dr. Nicole Edwards at EdwardsN@rowan.edu, or Dr. Zeynep Ercan at ercan@rowan.edu, but you do not have to give your personal identification.  

 

To participate in this survey, you must be 18 years or older, be a State Department / Division / Office ADMINISTRATOR overseeing services and supports for immigrant families and their young children (birth-5), and be willing to provide your voluntary consent (no signature/name needed to participate).

Q2: We work with many different programs and community patners. We provided education and refereals, some times we do direct services in dental screenings with fluoride varnish but a lot of what we do is training staff in WIC, Head Starts and Home Visiting. We also do workforce development in public health including guidlines for young children and motivational interviewing to dental students and dental hygiene students.
Q3_2_TEXT: I think over all this is true. A lot of them are scared. Those who have been in the US longer are more likely to advocate for them selves. Also if they have a agency or partner like prematoras they are more likely to advocate
Q4: In my expereinece the longer the family has been here the more likely they are to ask for services. Especially if they feel comfortable speaking English or have a trusted interperter. I have found that the children or 2nd generation are much more likely to seek out services. They often come with their parents to advocate on their behalf as well.
Q5_4_TEXT: I think it depends on the family and if they think there is a concern. In general they are more likely to advocate for their child then they are for them selves.
Q6: Again, I think in general 2nd generation parents feel more comfortable navigating and interacting with the system and are more likely to adovate for needed care. There are still often times cultural barriers and sometime not realizing the importance of some services - so education is key here also.
Q9_1_TEXT: We provided educational videos in multiple languages to address language barriers
Q10_1_TEXT: We got a lot of positive feedback and they are being used during pandemic
Q11_1_TEXT: We do targated educational trainings where we know a lot of immagrant families meet. We also partner with trusted community mamebers/ organizations that connect us with families.
Q13_2_TEXT: Education screenings and referals are great - we have limited capacity and lack of adult dental medicaid is a huge barrier - they don't always have an option for insurance or a way to pay providers when they do need care.
Q15: I agree with the suggestions above.
Q16: For us having families be on dental insurance and have providers that accept that insurance would be a game changer.
Q20: Public Health Hygienist Oral Health Educator

Q2: I don't believe they are addressed adequately at the present time. I think there are minimal services available for immigrant children 0-5, although there has been some focus on ways to strengthen this in the future.
Q3_2_TEXT: Given the current state of the US, immigrant families are far less likely to access services for various fears.
Q4: My answers would be the same. The only difference may be if a family's ability to speak english is improved. Then they would be able to access services easier, but there are still various worries.
Q6: I don't believe there is a large change.
Q9_2_TEXT: We are working on general equity trainings, but nothing specific to immigrant families.
Q12_1_TEXT: Unfortunately, this has not been a priority for the department, although it is recognized as an issue.
Q15: Although we don't have specific initiatives on immigrant families, we are focused on improving racial and ethnic disparities in the healthcare field. We are pushing to have improved training for staff and we are currently doing a disparities project to map out the issues seen throughout the state. This should have some impact into the work with immigrant families, although it is not directly related.
Q16: Policy related specific systems (e.g. healthcare, justice, child welfare, etc) as it relates to immigrants, language, disparities, etc.
Q26: Federal policies around anti-immigration create a large barrier for individuals accessing care. These should be changed if we want to better help immigrants.

Q2: All children in the state, including those born to immigrant families, are included in newborn screening (blood/heel stick, critical congenital heart disease, and hearing screening).  Families are encouraged to work with care coordinators at local health departments to ensure families are connected with health, social services, and educational services.   We seek to work with families through certified medical interpreters when interpretation is needed.
Q3_4_TEXT: Often families are more likely to seek services if their friends and neighbors have sought or are participating in similar services.....regardless of immigrant status.
Q4: Often, second generation immigrant families may be more likely to self-advocate given previous experience with the system (e.g. Medicaid, TANF, SNAP, etc.)
Q6: This is similar to the previous response:  positive experience navigating the safety net system can often leads to confidence with self-advocacy.
